fields.headline: Driver by Marina Blitshteyn
fields.bodyText: I was still the passenger in a belt strap seated staring at nothing in particular faking experience the way kids do there was a confession in the tan dashboard chalk-colored sky and wound-up cars, there was a silence in the armrests so the beat of the bass washed over us and the wheel could be easily coaxed to brush the curves. Suddenly direction was our construct, and the arms with my trust were foreign, not my father's, younger and anxiously comfortable. Suddenly the eyes of my own reflection in the window held secrets and threw smiles. Suddenly you smiled. I was still the passenger in a belt strap watching you drive the way kids do.
